citations.narrative:
One enclosure, housing one adult dog and three puppies, has sheets of white vinyl plastic covering the walls. Along the
front edge of the enclosure the dogs have ripped and torn the vinyl plastic exposing the wood beneath. The wood has
also been chewed and damaged by the animals. Damaged surfaces cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized which could
increase the risk of disease towards the animals.
All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities that cannot be readily cleaned and
sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled. The licensee must replace, repair, or alter the damaged vinyl plastic
and wood in a manner that allows for the surface to be readily cleaned and sanitized. The licensee must ensure that all
surfaces are properly maintained at all times.

Numerous bottles of cleaning supplies and a spray can of rust-oleum are stored on the floor of the housing facility.
Cleaning supplies and spray paint could be toxic to dogs if they should come into direct contact with them.
Substances that are toxic to the dogs may be stored in cabinets in the animal areas. The licensee must store the
cleaning supplies and rust-oleum in a cabinet or remove them from the housing facility when not in use. The licensee
must ensure all products used in the housing facility are properly stored at all times.

The puppies are housed in enclosures with raised plastic flooring. The inspector observed the feet and legs of one
dachshund puppy falling through the openings of the floor numerous times as it walked around the enclosure. Openings
in the flooring large enough to allow a dog's foot and leg to pass through could cause injury to the animal.
Primary enclosures must have floors that are constructed in a manner that protects the dogs' feet and legs from injury,
and that, if of mesh or slatted construction, do not allow the dogs' feet to pass through any openings in the floor. The
licensee must alter the flooring in a manner that does not allow the puppy's feet and legs to pass through any openings.
The licensee must ensure that all aspects of the enclosure, including flooring, are safe for the animals at all times.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class "A" license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 24-June-2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
